journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Evaluation by fast Fourier transforms analysis of energy harvesting in electrostrictive polymers driven by an electric field and a mechanical excitation

article-meta.aff: 1DAC HR Laboratory, Ferhat Abbas University, Sétif, Algeria
2Laboratoire de Génie Electrique et Ferroélectricité (LGEF), INSA LYON, Villeurbanne, Cedex, France
3Laboratoire de la physique de la matière condensée, Faculté des sciences, Université Chouaib Doukkali, El Jadida, Morocco
4Ecole nationale des sciences appliquées, Université Chouaib Doukkali, El Jadida, Morocco
5Hassan II Academy of Science and Technology, Rabat, Morocco

author-notes.corresp: Abdelowahed Hajjaji, Laboratoire de Génie Electrique et Ferroélectricité (LGEF), INSA LYON, Bat. Gustave Ferrie, 69621 Villeurbanne Cedex, France. Email: hajjaji.a@ucd.ac.ma

abstract.p: Electrostrictive polymers offer the promise of energy harvesting with few moving parts where power can be produced simply by stretching and contracting a relatively low-cost rubbery material. The use of such polymers for energy harvesting is a growing field, which has great potential from an energy density viewpoint. Basically, the relative energy gain depends on the current induced by the mechanical strain and frequency. A previous study in the Laboratoire de Génie Electrique et Ferroélectricité laboratory has indicated that one can measure the dielectric constant, the Young’s modulus, and the electrostrictive coefficient of a polymer film by determining the current flowing through the sample when the polymer film was simultaneously driven by an electrical field and mechanical excitation. The goal of this study has thus been to develop a solution for artificially increasing the coupling factor of electrostrictive materials, based on the optimization of the frequency of the electric field and the amplitude strain of the mechanical excitation leading to an increase in the generated current. When relating this parameter with a transverse strain of 5% and a bias field of 10 V/µm, it was found that such a process rendered it able to increase the converted power to 14 µW at a mechanical frequency of 6 Hz. The converted power was much higher than for the frequency of 3 Hz for which a low power was consumed by the polarization of the polymer. The theoretical analysis was supported by the experimental investigations. The contribution of this study provides a framework for developing energy harvesting techniques that should improve the overall performance of the system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the development of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) during the last decade, the request for wearable electronics and cordless detectors has become increasingly important. These wearable devices need more battery lifetime (Amirtharajah and Chandrakasan, 1997; Kansal et al., 2004; Meninger et al., 2001; Rahimi et al., 2003) and independence in energy for powering ubiquitously deployed sensor networks and mobile electronics (Paradiso and Starner, 2005). Thus, scientists have been forced to search for new power sources that are able to recover energy from the environment (Paradiso and Starner, 2005; Ren et al., 2007). As an example, electrostrictive polymers offer unique properties for the electromechanical transducer technology in comparison with conventional techniques such as those based on piezoelectrics or electromagnetics (Guillot and Balizer, 2003; Liu et al., 1998). Piezoelectrics are limited in terms of the strains they can sustain; however, they are capable of operating at high frequencies. Electrostrictive polymers, on the other hand, are generally capable of sustaining much larger strains, have flexible form factors, and are more suitable for low-frequency applications. Moreover, these materials are characterized by very high theoretical energy densities and good coupling efficiencies (Pelrine et al., 2000).

In order to achieve the abovementioned purpose, many studies have been performed on electrostrictive polymers to predict their energy harvesting capabilities by increasing the permittivity or incorporating conductive nanoparticles (Cottinet et al., 2011a; Lallart et al., 2010; Lebrun et al., 2009). Other investigations, such as those performed by Liu et al. (2004) and Ren et al. (2007), have focused on the optimization of the energy transfer process through the use of proper interfaces. Guyomar et al. (2011a) proposed a simple but original method that enables measuring the dielectric constant, the Young’s modulus, and the electrostrictive coefficient of a polymer film. The method was based on fast Fourier transform (FFT) analysis of the current flowing through the sample when the latter was simultaneously driven by an electrical field and a mechanical excitation.

The objective of this study is to evaluate the power harvesting by FFT analyses in order to increase the conversion abilities of electrostrictive polymers. It has been shown that there exists a strong relationship between the amplitude of the current components, the corresponding pulsation of the mechanical excitation ωm, and the pulsation of the electrical excitation ωe in order to achieve high power harvesting than that consumed by the polarization.

sec.title: Modeling and abilities analysis
sec.p: Electrostriction is generally defined as a quadratic coupling between strain and electric field. Assuming a linear relationship between the polarization and the electric field, the strain Sij and electric flux density Dm are expressed as independent variables of the electric field intensities Em and En and stress Tij by the following constitutive relations (Liu et al., 2005)

where sijklE is the elastic compliance, Mijkl is the electric-field-related electrostriction coefficient, and εijklT is the linear dielectric permittivity. An isotropic electrostrictive polymer film contracts along the thickness direction and expands along the film direction when an electric field is applied across the thickness, assuming that only non-zero stress is applied along the length of the film (the condition of the setup; Figure 3). The constitutive relations are then simplified as
The electric displacement, D3, flowing through the polymer film can be calculated from equation (3) and from the expressions of S1 and E3 by replacing T1 with T1=(S1−M31E32)/s11E
The electric displacement, D3, on the electrostrictive element can be expressed in the frequency domain by equation (4)
Here, * corresponds to the convolution and ~ corresponds to the frequency domain.
Moreover, the expression of E3 and S1 in the frequency domain is given by the following equations
with δ as the delta function.

Since the current I through the polymer film can be calculated by the derivation of the D3 expression (I=D3•A; with A referring to the sample area), the current is given by equation (5) (Guyomar et al., 2011a)

The contribution of the electrical losses to the current cannot be neglected for the studied polymer (Fujisaki et al., 2007), whereas the mechanical loss contribution can be considered. The electrical losses have been added to the expression of I as Edc/(Rdc…t) for the direct current (DC) component. Here, Rdc is the resistance of the polymer film. The Rdc value is measured using a Keithley electrometer 6517 A. With new expressions of Bi, it then becomes possible to calculate the different parameters of the electrostrictive materials

This is done by measuring B1, B2, B5, and B6, which are the amplitude of the current components ωm, ωe, ωm+ωe, and ωm−ωe, respectively. S0 is the amplitude of the imposed strain and Edc is the DC component of the applied field E3. The different values of coefficients are available in Table 1.

caption.p: Summary of the values of Bi calculated from equation (5).

sec.title: Polymers material and preparation
sec.p: Among the commercially available polymers, we based this study on polyurethane (PU) loaded with carbon black nanopowder (C). These PU composites were prepared in the laboratory, using the 58887 thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU) elastomer (Estane) as matrix. Filled PU films were prepared by solution casting (Guiffard, et al., 2006; Petit et al., 2008). The PU granules were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 80°C for 45 min, and the inorganic fillers (i.e. the carbon black nanopowder (C)) were individually dispersed in DMF through ultrasonication. Subsequently, the carbon black nanopowder (C) was mixed with the dissolved PU under mechanical stirring at 80°C for 1 h, after which this viscous mixture was poured onto glass plates and cured at 50°C for 24 h to remove most of the solvent.

The thus-obtained samples of the PU composite films filled with 0.5% C represented a rectangular capacitor. Gold electrodes were sputtered onto both sides of the specimens, and the area of the electrodes was 1.8 × 4.0 cm2 (Figure 1). Permittivity measurements were carried out using a Solartron 1255, 1296 interface, and the Young’s modulus of our films was evaluated on a Newport table. The results of the measurement performed at 1 Hz are summarized in Table 2.

caption.p: Dimension of the polymer sample with gold electrodes.
PU: polyurethane.
Various properties of the PU composites.

sec.p: The dielectric constant was calculated from the capacitance at room temperature using the formula below

where cp, t, s, and ε0 are the capacity, the thickness, the area of the electrode from the sample, and vacuum permittivity, respectively. Tan δ is the dissipation factor that equals ε″/ε′, where ε′ is the permittivity (or dielectric constant) and ε″ is the resistive effect as dielectric loss. In materials, where ε″ is very small and ε′ is large, the resolution of tan δ becomes critical if an accurate measurement is to be made. The ε″ can be obtained by the following relationship
with ε′=εr×ε0.
The results are presented in Figure 2. These experimental values show that the permittivity and the loss index (D) are decreased with an increasing frequency.

caption.p: Dielectric permittivity and loss (D) as a function of the frequency.

sec.p: This section presents the experimental observations and their analysis. In order to provide a relationship between stress and strain, these measurements were performed using the Newport table with one degree of freedom. Figure 3 illustrates the operating principle. The test sample was clamped between two jaws, one mobile side was connected to the table with one degree of freedom, and the other side was fixed because it is connected to the force sensor. The Young’s modulus followed a linear function of strain and stress. However, when the elongation became higher, the curve derived from this linear trend of the strain and a significant hysteresis loop appeared, thus reflecting the existence of mechanical losses (cf. Figure 4). But for the frequencies below 100 Hz, it is interesting to note that the mechanical losses in the polymer are low. This occurs for high frequencies with an increase in Young’s modulus. This behaviour is crucial because it help to define the optimal operating range, within which it is possible to use polymers for energy harvesting at a given temperature. Indeed, for the frequency band where the maximum loss occurs, the efficacy of our polymers, such as energy harvesting, will not be optimal as much mechanical energy is dissipated as heat.

caption.p: A schematic diagram and a photograph of the experimental setup for measuring the stress–strain behavior in electrostrictive polymers.
GBF: Function generator.
The stress as a function of strain for PU 0.5% C.
PU: polyurethane.

sec.title: Principle
sec.p: To prove the theoretical results, the PU samples were tested in an electromechanical test rig. Figure 5 provides a schematic representation of the setup for characterizing the harvested current and power. The key part of the setup was a system on which the polymer film was attached; the polymer film was mounted in a sample holder composed of a tow part and another part that could be moved in one direction with the help of an XM550 Ironless linear motor. The film was stretched with a maximum strain amplitude of 5% at fm = 3 Hz and fm = 6 Hz. It was assumed that the sample strained along the one direction, by applying electric field using a function generator (Agilent 33220A), connected to the high voltage amplifier (Trek 609D-6) in order to apply an electric field. It was necessary to induce a DC-bias polarization since the polymer was not piezoelectric, and this was applied in addition to a low alternating current (AC) component with a frequency fe = 1 Hz. The sample was connected to an electrical load (Rc), and the current was monitored by a current amplifier (Keithley 617). The root mean square (RMS) power harvested on the load was subsequently derived using Pharvested = RC I2, where I was the current measured by the current amplifier.

caption.p: Schematic illustration of the experimental setup for the energy harvesting measurements.

sec.p: Preliminary measurements for the determination of the theoretical harvested power were also performed to evaluate the harmonic current corresponding to fe and fm. The first part of this experimental setup for measuring the current under short-circuit conditions was carried out at an electrical field of 1 Hz with a bias field (Edc) of 10 kV/mm for a constant strain of 5% and for two mechanical excitation frequencies of 3 and 6 Hz.

sec.title: Validation of the model
sec.p: To assess the validity of the model, various measurements were carried out. The modeling and experimentation were realized as displays of the harmonic analysis of the short-circuit current. Consequently, the power harvested by the polymer could be expressed as Pharvested = RC I2, where RC is the electrical load. These experimental measurements of the harvested current showed all the predicted frequencies. Figure 6(a) depicts current and electric field versus time, and Figure 6(b) presents the FFT of the current with fe = 1 and fm =3 Hz. It can be seen that B2 = 6.07 × 10−7 A and B1 = 4.297 × 10−7 A. However, experimentally, the amplitude of the B2 coefficient remained constant and was much smaller than that of B1, which reached a value of 7.677 × 10−7 A as indicated in Figure 7(a) and (b).

caption.p: (a) The current and electric field versus time. (b) FFT of the short-circuit current with fm = 3 Hz.
FFT: fast Fourier transform.
(a) The current and electric field versus time. (b) FFT of the short-circuit current with fm = 6 Hz.
FFT: fast Fourier transform.

sec.p: It has been shown in previous study (Cottinet et al., 2011b; Eury et al., 1999; Gallone et al., 2007). In this case, it was clear from equation (8) that increasing the coefficient B1 with the constant ratio (M31/s11E), (since from Table 1 the coefficient B2 remains constant), would increase εijklT.

caption.p: Photograph of the experimental setup for measuring the harvested current in the electrostrictive polymers.

sec.p: The results demonstrate that the proposed operating mode at a 1-Hz electrical field, with a bias field (Edc) of 10 kV/mm for a constant strain of 5%, fm remained constant at 6 Hz. One can notice from Figure 9 that the rays of the measured current varied with the load and that the amplitude of the rays decreased with an increasing load. However, at a load of 10 and 60 MΩ (cf. Figure 9(a) and (b)), the amplitude corresponding to fm was higher than for fe, indicating that the harvested power was higher than that of polarization. Above 60 Ω (cf. Figure 9(c)), we see a reversible effect. The amplitude corresponding to fm became lower than that of fe, which signifies that there was an optimum operating mode for the harvested energy. The values measured in this experiment are shown in Table 3.

caption.p: FFT of the current with fm = 6 Hz: (a) RC = 10 MΩ, (b) RC = 60 MΩ, and (c) RC = 90 MΩ.
FFT: fast Fourier transform.
Evaluation of the amplitude of the current components at different loads for fe =1 Hz and fm = 6 Hz.

sec.p: The aim of this section was to study the harvested power for various configurations and different operating regimes, with constant mechanical excitation amplitudes, and two frequencies (i.e. 3 and 6 Hz). In order to assess the validity of the two states, various measurements were carried out. Figure 10 presents the power versus electric load for a given electric field E3 = Edc+E0 cos(ωe t) with Edc = 10 MV/m, E0 = 2 MV/m at fe = 1 Hz. Moreover, the strain was 5%. These data showed the existence of a maximum power harvested at an optimal load resistance as expected according to Figure 9(b). The power harvesting using 3 Hz of mechanical excitation was lower than that using 6 Hz. Moreover, the model and FFT analysis demonstrated that the power harvesting was proportional to the frequencies of the mechanical excitation.

caption.p: Power harvested with a constant strain 5% at fe = 1 Hz under different fm values of 3 and 6 Hz.

sec.p: Figure 10 shows that the power harvesting was 8.498 μW for a system working with fm = 3 Hz. However, a value of 14.83 μW was achieved with fm = 6 Hz. Moreover, the difference between the power harvesting was due to the intrinsic characteristics. According to the calculation of the constants B1, B2, B5, and B6 in Table 1, we found that the ratio M/s remained almost constant for both frequency of mechanical excitation (for fm = 3 Hz, M31/s11E = 7.257 × 10−8 and fm = 6 Hz, M31/s11E = 7.284 × 10−8).

Increasing the amplitude of B1 because of the increase in frequency led to a noticeable change of the permittivity. This parameter was essential in order to achieve elevated values of the harvested power. The most important point in this experimental study was for the efficiency of the conversion to be positive since the harvested power was higher than that consumed. However, with loads exceeding 90 MΩ, the polarization power became greater than that harvested. This shows that there is an optimal operation for a positive performance, which links the three parameters of strain amplitude and frequencies fm and fe.

It has been shown in previous study (Guyomar et al., 2011b) that the total energy density dWconv converted by the electrostrictive polymer yields: dWconv≈M31YE0EdcdS. Hence, the conversion performance of electrostrictive materials may be obtained from the area of the electric field strain. A comparison of the converted energy density between the two regimes of operation, that is, fm = 3 Hz and fm= 6 Hz, is displayed in Figure 11. This figure shows that the two areas differed markedly under these conditions. However, thanks to the increase in the electrostrictive coupling, the fm = 6 Hz approach outperformed the case with fm = 3 Hz. For this working prototype, the RMS power density was 43.7 µW/cm3 at 6 Hz, which is comparable to the value obtained by most piezo-based harvesters. For example, Kim et al. (2008) realized a device that was able to generate power of 301.3 µW/cm3 at 870 Hz. The power density for this working model demonstrated the excellent potential of electrostrictive polymer for energy harvesting.

caption.p: Comparison of conversion cycles for two operating modes: fm = 3 and fm = 6 Hz.

sec.p: By reducing the scales of the equipment thanks to the MEMS, consumption in energy also decreased, and it becomes possible to feed the microsystem; while being useful only of energy present in the environment the frequencies of the vibratory sources present in our environment are generally lower than 100 Hz. These structures of recuperation of energy aim at the applications where the produced vibrations are of low frequency, distributed on a broad frequency band, and are thus compatible with many applications in the field of transport (cars, planes etc.), of industry (machines etc.), and of medicine (pacemakers autonomous etc.).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article proposes the application of FFT analysis for increasing the conversion abilities of electrostrictive polymers. In each case, a good agreement between the model and the experimental data was found. According to the experimental results, this model rendered it possible to point out the influence of the mechanical parameters (mechanical frequency and amplitude mechanical) on the overall performance of the electromechanical conversion for electrostrictive polymers. The results demonstrated the excellent potential of this technique for energy harvesting. Regardless the case considered the current harvested related amplitude strain and mechanical frequency excitation; this study points out three important parameters: the ratio M/s remained almost constant with increasing mechanical frequency, change of the permittivity, and increase in the harvested current. Such a treatment therefore permits a significant increase in terms of converted power. Electrostrictive polymers are thus promising candidates for replacing piezoelectric lead zirconate titanate (PZT) materials in certain applications (smart textile). The analysis developed in this study could represent a good tool for estimating energy harvesting capabilities in the future.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
